  <script>
    (function () {
      const generateUUID = () =>
        "xxxxxxxx-xxxx-4xxx-yxxx-xxxxxxxxxxxx".replace(/[xy]/g, function (c) {
          const r = (Math.random() * 16) | 0;
          const v = c === "x" ? r : (r & 0x3) | 0x8;
          return v.toString(16);
        });
  
      let isLocalStorageAvailable = false;
      const isAvailable = () => {
        if (isLocalStorageAvailable) {
          return true;
        }
  
        try {
          const x = "__storage_test__";
          window.localStorage.setItem(x, x);
          window.localStorage.removeItem(x);
          isLocalStorageAvailable = true;
          return true;
        } catch (e) {
          return false;
        }
      };
  
      const unsafeSetItem = (key, value) => {
        window.localStorage.setItem(key, JSON.stringify(value));
      };
  
      const unsafeGetItem = (key) => {
        return JSON.parse(window.localStorage.getItem(key) || "null");
      };
  
      const setSafeItem = (key, value) => {
        if (isAvailable()) {
          unsafeSetItem(key, value);
        }
      };
  
      const getSafeItem = (key, defaultValue) => {
        return isAvailable() ? unsafeGetItem(key) : defaultValue;
      };
  
      const ANA_UID_KEY = "ana_uid";
      let currentUid = getSafeItem(ANA_UID_KEY, "");
      if (!currentUid) {
        currentUid = generateUUID();
        setSafeItem(ANA_UID_KEY, currentUid);
      }
      window.getAnaUid = () => currentUid;
    })();
  </script>

  <script>
  function initialize_wunderkind(d) {
    window.addEventListener('load', function() {
      var e = d.createElement('script');
      e.src = d.location.protocol + '//tag.wknd.ai/5453/i.js';
      e.async = true;
      d.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(e);
    });
  }

  function determine_wunderkind_eligibility() {
    if (window.location.search.includes('enable_wunderkind')) {
      initialize_wunderkind(document);
      return;
    }

    let wunderkind_segment = 0;
    try { wunderkind_segment = localStorage.getItem('genius_wunderkind_segment'); } catch (e) {}

    if (typeof(wunderkind_segment) === 'string') {
      wunderkind_segment = Number(wunderkind_segment);
    } else {
      wunderkind_segment = Math.random();
      try { localStorage.setItem('genius_wunderkind_segment', wunderkind_segment); } catch (e) {}
    }

    if ((wunderkind_segment * 100) < 100.0) {
      window['com.Genius.wunderkind_cohort'] = 'wunderkind';
      initialize_wunderkind(document);
    } else {
      window['com.Genius.wunderkind_cohort'] = 'control';
    }
  }

  determine_wunderkind_eligibility();
</script>

class="About__Container-ut4i9m-1 eSiFpi"><h1 font-size="xxLargeHeadline" class="About__Title-ut4i9m-2 kcXwIY">About</h1><div class="SongDescription__Container-sc-615rvk-0 hYPlhL"><div class="Attribution__Container-sc-1nmry9o-0 dhIhSa"><div class="Attribution__Header-sc-1nmry9o-1 iPNsXE"><span>Genius Annotation</span><button text-decoration="underline" type="button" class="TextButton-sc-192nsqv-0 ixMmYX">6 contributors</button></div></div><div class="ExpandableContent__Container-sc-1165iv-0 ikywhQ"><div class="ExpandableContent__Content-sc-1165iv-4 huhsMa"><div class="SongDescription__Content-sc-615rvk-2 kRzyD"><div class="RichText__Container-oz284w-0 fcIjxB"><p>The Cranberries describe the violence in “The Troubles,” the decades-long conflict in Northern Ireland between nationalists (mainly self-identified as Irish or Roman Catholic) and unionists (mainly self-identified as British or Protestant).</p>

<p>Dolores O'Riordan wrote the song during the band’s English tour in 1993 in memory of two young boys, Tim Parry and Johnathan Ball, who were killed in an IRA bombing in Warrington, England.</p>

<blockquote><p>“This song is our cry against man’s inhumanity to man, inhumanity to child,” she said.</p></blockquote>

<p>During a performance of “Zombie” in January 1994 at The Astoria in London, Dolores O'Riordan said:</p>

<blockquote><p>This song is our cry against the violence in London, against the war in the north of Ireland. And we want it to stop.</p></blockquote></div></div></div><div class="ExpandableContent__ButtonContainer-sc-1165iv-3 jzPNvv"><button class="Button__Container-rtu9rw-0 efSZT loEclW"><span>What did The Cranberries say about "Zombie"?</span><button class="TextButton-sc-192nsqv-0 hVAZmF QuestionTemplate__ExpandButton-sc-1is5n1p-5 RSOwl" type="button"><svg width="24" class="Attribution__Header-sc-1nmry9o-1 iPNsXE"><span><div class="Answer__AttributionLabel-sc-2neq6u-3 doQBGH">Genius Answer</div></span><button text-decoration="underline" type="button" <iframe loading="lazy" type="text/html" width="640" height="390" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="1" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/2ab8OxbEnvk?modestbranding=1&start=0&showinfo=0&enablejsapi=1&origin=genius.com"></iframe>
</div></div></div></div><div class="QuestionAnswerActions__Container-sc-6ne2ji-0 dTXIVU"></div></div><div class="QuestionTemplate__Container-sc-1is5n1p-1 cgTISK"><div class="QuestionTemplate__Title-sc-1is5n1p-4 loEclW"><span>What have the artists said about the making of this song?</span><button class="TextButton-sc-192nsqv-0 hVAZmF QuestionTemplate__ExpandButton-sc-1is5n1p-5 RSOwl" type="button"><svg width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24"><path d="M0 10h24v4h-24z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="Answer__Container-sc-2neq6u-0 iHvEbL"><div class="Attribution__Container-sc-1nmry9o-0 dhIhSa"><div class="Attribution__Header-sc-1nmry9o-1 iPNsXE"><span><div class="Answer__AttributionLabel-sc-2neq6u-3 doQBGH">Genius Answer</div></span><button text-decoration="underline" type="button" class="TextButton-sc-192nsqv-0 ixMmYX">1 contributor</button></div></div><div class="Answer__Body-sc-2neq6u-1 fzIWba"><div class="RichText__Container-oz284w-0 fcIjxB"><p>In an <a href="https://www.loudersound.com/features/the-story-behind-the-song-the-cranberries-zombie" rel="noopener nofollow">interview with <em>Louder Sound,</em></a> O'Riordian recalls:</p>

<blockquote><p>It was extremely busy and we were working all the time around the clock,” she said. “That song came to me when I was in Limerick, and I wrote it initially on an acoustic guitar, late at night. I remember being in my flat, coming up with the chorus, which was catchy and anthemic. So I took it into rehearsals, and I picked up the electric guitar. Then I kicked in distortion on the chorus, and I said to Ferg [Fergal Lawler, drums]: ‘Maybe you could beat the drums pretty hard.’ Even though it was written on an acoustic, it became a bit of a rocker….It came organically because we were using our live instruments, we were plugging in a lot, and we started to mess around with feedback and distortion. When you’re on tour you start to mess around a bit more with the live side of things. There were a lot of bands around that were part of the grunge thing, and this wasn’t grunge, but the timing was good. We couldn’t have really fitted in with grunge, because we were just a different type of a band. We were Irish and from Limerick, and we had a lot of our own ideas. A lot of the grunge bands were very similar to each other.</p></blockquote></div></div></div><div class="QuestionAnswerActions__Container-sc-6ne2ji-0 dTXIVU"></div></div><div class="QuestionTemplate__Container-sc-1is5n1p-1 cgTISK"><div class="QuestionTemplate__Title-sc-1is5n1p-4 loEclW"><span>Is there a live performance video for this song?</span><button class="TextButton-sc-192nsqv-0 hVAZmF QuestionTemplate__ExpandButton-sc-1is5n1p-5 RSOwl" type="button"><svg width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24"><path d="M0 10h24v4h-24z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="Answer__Container-sc-2neq6u-0 iHvEbL"><div class="Attribution__Container-sc-1nmry9o-0 dhIhSa"><div class="Attribution__Header-sc-1nmry9o-1 iPNsXE"><span><div class="Answer__AttributionLabel-sc-2neq6u-3 doQBGH">Genius Answer</div></span><button text-decoration="underline" type="button" class="TextButton-sc-192nsqv-0 ixMmYX">2 contributors</button></div></div><div class="Answer__Body-sc-2neq6u-1 fzIWba"><div class="RichText__Container-oz284w-0 fcIjxB"><p>Yes! The Cranberries performed “Zombie” at NPR’s <em>Tiny Desk Concert.</em></p>

child,” she said.\\n\\nDuring a performance of “Zombie” in January 1994 at The Astoria in London, Dolores O\'Riordan said:\\n\\nThis song is our cry against the violence in London, against the war in the north of Ireland. And we want it to stop.\",\"html\":\"<p>The Cranberries describe the violence in “The Troubles,” the decades-long conflict in Northern Ireland between nationalists (mainly self-identified as Irish or Roman Catholic) and unionists (mainly self-identified as British or Protestant).<\/p>\\n\\n<p>Dolores O\'Riordan wrote the song during the band’s English tour in 1993 in memory of two young boys, Tim Parry and Johnathan Ball, who were killed in an IRA bombing in Warrington, England.<\/p>\\n\\n<blockquote><p>“This song is our cry against man’s inhumanity to man, inhumanity to child,” she said.<\/p><\/blockquote>\\n\\n<p>During a performance of “Zombie” in January 1994 at The Astoria in London, Dolores O\'Riordan said:<\/p>\\n\\n<blockquote><p>This song is our cry against the violence in London, against the war in the north of Ireland. Troubles were not a conflict *between* Ireland and the UK (which are both sovereign countries). Instead, The Troubles were a period of sectarian violence *within* Northern Ireland (which is a part of the UK but not a part of Ireland). The Republicans, which were overwhelming catholic, wanted to see Northern Ireland join Ireland while the Unionists, who were overwhelming protestant, wanted to ensure Northern Ireland remained a part of the United Kingdom. Basically it was a civil war within the UK and not a war between Ireland the UK.\",\"html\":\"<p>The Troubles were not a conflict <em>between<\/em> Ireland and the UK (which are both sovereign countries). Instead, The Troubles were a period of sectarian violence <em>within<\/em> Northern Ireland (which is a part of the UK but not a part of Ireland). The Republicans, which were overwhelming catholic, wanted to see Northern Ireland join Ireland while the Unionists, who were overwhelming protestant, wanted to ensure Northern Ireland remained a part of the United Kingdom. Basically it was a civil war within the UK and not a war between Ireland the I remember being in my flat, coming up with the chorus, which was catchy and anthemic. So I took it into rehearsals, and I picked up the electric guitar. Then I kicked in distortion on the chorus, and I said to Ferg [Fergal Lawler, drums]: ‘Maybe you could beat the drums pretty hard.’ Even though it was written on an acoustic, it became a bit of a rocker....It came organically because we were using our live instruments, we were plugging in a lot, and we started to mess around with feedback and distortion. When you’re on tour you start to mess around a bit more with the live side of things. There were a lot of bands around that were part of the grunge thing, and this wasn’t grunge, but the timing was good. We couldn’t have really fitted in with grunge, because we were just a different type of a band. We were Irish and from Limerick, and we had a lot of our own ideas. A lot of the grunge bands were very similar to each other.\",\"body\":{\"markdown\":\"In an [interview with *Louder Sound,*](https://www.loudersound.com/features/the-story-behind-the-song-the-cranberries-zombie) O\'Riordian recalls:\\n\\n>It was extremely busy and we were working all the time around the clock,” she said. “That song came to me when I was in Limerick, and I wrote it initially on an acoustic guitar, late at night. I remember being in my flat, coming up with the chorus, which was catchy and anthemic. So I took it into rehearsals, and I picked up the electric guitar. Then I kicked in distortion on the chorus, and I said to Ferg [Fergal Lawler, drums]: ‘Maybe you could beat the drums pretty hard.’ Even though it was written on an acoustic, it became a bit of a rocker....It came organically because we were using our live instruments, we were plugging in a lot, and we started to mess around with feedback and distortion. When you’re on tour you start to mess around a bit more with the live side of things. There were a lot of bands around that were part of the grunge thing, and this wasn’t grunge, but the timing was good. We couldn’t have really fitted in with grunge, because we were just a different type of a band. We were Irish and from Limerick, and we had a lot of our own ideas. A lot of the grunge bands were very similar to each other.\",\"html\":\"<p>In an <a href=\\\"https://www.loudersound.com/features/the-story-behind-the-song-the-cranberries-zombie\\\" rel=\\\"noopener nofollow\\\">interview with <em>Louder Sound,<\/em><\/a> O\'Riordian recalls:<\/p>\\n\\n<blockquote><p>It was extremely busy and we were working all the time around the clock,” she said. “That song came to me when I was in Limerick, and I wrote it initially on an acoustic guitar, late at night. I remember being in my flat, coming up with the chorus, which was catchy and anthemic. So I took it into rehearsals, and I picked up the electric guitar. Then I kicked in distortion on the chorus, and I said to Ferg [Fergal Lawler, drums]: ‘Maybe you could beat the drums pretty hard.’ Even though it was written on an acoustic, it became a bit of a rocker….It came organically because we were using our live instruments, we were plugging in a lot, and we started to mess around with feedback and distortion. When you’re on tour you start to mess around a bit more with the live side of things. There were a lot of bands around that were part of the grunge thing, and this wasn’t grunge, but the timing was good. We couldn’t have really fitted in with grunge, because we were just a different type of a band. We were Irish and from Limerick, and we had a lot of our own ideas. A lot of the grunge bands were very similar to each   <script>
    (function () {
      const generateUUID = () =>
        "xxxxxxxx-xxxx-4xxx-yxxx-xxxxxxxxxxxx".replace(/[xy]/g, function (c) {
          const r = (Math.random() * 16) | 0;
          const v = c === "x" ? r : (r & 0x3) | 0x8;
          return v.toString(16);
        });
  
      let isLocalStorageAvailable = false;
      const isAvailable = () => {
        if (isLocalStorageAvailable) {
          return true;
        }
  
        try {
          const x = "__storage_test__";
          window.localStorage.setItem(x, x);
          window.localStorage.removeItem(x);
          isLocalStorageAvailable = true;
          return true;
        } catch (e) {
          return false;
        }
      };
  
      const unsafeSetItem = (key, value) => {
        window.localStorage.setItem(key, JSON.stringify(value));
      };
  
      const unsafeGetItem = (key) => {
        return JSON.parse(window.localStorage.getItem(key) || "null");
      };
  
      const setSafeItem = (key, value) => {
        if (isAvailable()) {
          unsafeSetItem(key, value);
        }
      };
  
      const getSafeItem = (key, defaultValue) => {
        return isAvailable() ? unsafeGetItem(key) : defaultValue;
      };
  
      const ANA_UID_KEY = "ana_uid";
      let currentUid = getSafeItem(ANA_UID_KEY, "");
      if (!currentUid) {
        currentUid = generateUUID();
        setSafeItem(ANA_UID_KEY, currentUid);
      }
      window.getAnaUid = () => currentUid;
    })();
  </script>

  <script>
  function initialize_wunderkind(d) {
    window.addEventListener('load', function() {
      var e = d.createElement('script');
      e.src = d.location.protocol + '//tag.wknd.ai/5453/i.js';
      e.async = true;
      d.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(e);
    });
  }

  function determine_wunderkind_eligibility() {
    if (window.location.search.includes('enable_wunderkind')) {
      initialize_wunderkind(document);
      return;
    }

    let wunderkind_segment = 0;
    try { wunderkind_segment = localStorage.getItem('genius_wunderkind_segment'); } catch (e) {}

    if (typeof(wunderkind_segment) === 'string') {
      wunderkind_segment = Number(wunderkind_segment);
    } else {
      wunderkind_segment = Math.random();
      try { localStorage.setItem('genius_wunderkind_segment', wunderkind_segment); } catch (e) {}
    }

    if ((wunderkind_segment * 100) < 100.0) {
      window['com.Genius.wunderkind_cohort'] = 'wunderkind';
      initialize_wunderkind(document);
    } else {
      window['com.Genius.wunderkind_cohort'] = 'control';
    }
  }

  determine_wunderkind_eligibility();
</script>

class="SongDescription__Content-sc-615rvk-2 kRzyD"><div class="RichText__Container-oz284w-0 fcIjxB"><p>The Cranberries describe the violence in “The Troubles,” the decades-long conflict in Northern Ireland between nationalists (mainly self-identified as Irish or Roman Catholic) and unionists (mainly self-identified as British or Protestant).</p>

<p>Dolores O'Riordan wrote the song during the band’s English tour in 1993 in memory of two young boys, Tim Parry and Johnathan Ball, who were killed in an IRA bombing in Warrington, England.</p>

<blockquote><p>“This song is our cry against man’s inhumanity to man, inhumanity to child,” she said.</p></blockquote>

<p>During a performance of “Zombie” in January 1994 at The Astoria in London, Dolores O'Riordan said:</p>

<blockquote><p>This song is our cry against the violence in London, against the war in the north of Ireland. And we want it to stop.</p></blockquote></div></div></div><div class="ExpandableContent__ButtonContainer-sc-1165iv-3 jzPNvv"><button class="Button__Container-rtu9rw-0 efSZT <iframe loading="lazy" type="text/html" width="640" height="390" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="1" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/2ab8OxbEnvk?modestbranding=1&start=0&showinfo=0&enablejsapi=1&origin=genius.com"></iframe>
</div></div></div></div><div class="QuestionAnswerActions__Container-sc-6ne2ji-0 dTXIVU"></div></div><div class="QuestionTemplate__Container-sc-1is5n1p-1 cgTISK"><div class="QuestionTemplate__Title-sc-1is5n1p-4 loEclW"><span>What have the artists said about the making of this song?</span><button class="TextButton-sc-192nsqv-0 hVAZmF QuestionTemplate__ExpandButton-sc-1is5n1p-5 RSOwl" type="button"><svg width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24"><path d="M0 10h24v4h-24z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="Answer__Container-sc-2neq6u-0 iHvEbL"><div class="Attribution__Container-sc-1nmry9o-0 dhIhSa"><div class="Attribution__Header-sc-1nmry9o-1 iPNsXE"><span><div class="Answer__AttributionLabel-sc-2neq6u-3 doQBGH">Genius Answer</div></span><button text-decoration="underline" type="button" class="TextButton-sc-192nsqv-0 ixMmYX">1 contributor</button></div></div><div class="Answer__Body-sc-2neq6u-1 fzIWba"><div class="RichText__Container-oz284w-0 fcIjxB"><p>In an <a href="https://www.loudersound.com/features/the-story-behind-the-song-the-cranberries-zombie" rel="noopener nofollow">interview with <em>Louder Sound,</em></a> O'Riordian recalls:</p>

<blockquote><p>It was extremely busy and we were working all the time around the clock,” she said. “That song came to me when I was in Limerick, and I wrote it initially on an acoustic guitar, late at night. I remember being in my flat, coming up with the chorus, which was catchy and anthemic. So I took it into rehearsals, and I picked up the electric guitar. Then I kicked in distortion on the chorus, and I said to Ferg [Fergal Lawler, drums]: ‘Maybe you could beat the drums pretty hard.’ Even though it was written on an acoustic, it became a bit of a rocker….It came organically because we were using our live instruments, we were plugging in a lot, and we started to mess around with feedback and distortion. When you’re on tour you start to mess around a bit more with the live side of things. There were a lot of bands around that were part of the grunge thing, and this wasn’t grunge, but the timing was good. We couldn’t have really fitted in with grunge, because we were just a different type of a band. We were Irish and from Limerick, and we had a lot of our own ideas. A lot of the grunge bands were very similar to each other.</p></blockquote></div></div></div><div class="QuestionAnswerActions__Container-sc-6ne2ji-0 dTXIVU"></div></div><div class="QuestionTemplate__Container-sc-1is5n1p-1 cgTISK"><div class="QuestionTemplate__Title-sc-1is5n1p-4 loEclW"><span>Is there a live performance video for this song?</span><button class="TextButton-sc-192nsqv-0 hVAZmF QuestionTemplate__ExpandButton-sc-1is5n1p-5 RSOwl" type="button"><svg width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24"><path d="M0 10h24v4h-24z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="Answer__Container-sc-2neq6u-0 iHvEbL"><div class="Attribution__Container-sc-1nmry9o-0 dhIhSa"><div class="Attribution__Header-sc-1nmry9o-1 iPNsXE"><span><div class="Answer__AttributionLabel-sc-2neq6u-3 doQBGH">Genius Answer</div></span><button text-decoration="underline" type="button" class="TextButton-sc-192nsqv-0 ixMmYX">2 contributors</button></div></div><div class="Answer__Body-sc-2neq6u-1 fzIWba"><div class="RichText__Container-oz284w-0 fcIjxB"><p>Yes! The Cranberries performed “Zombie” at NPR’s <em>Tiny Desk Concert.</em></p>

in 1993 in memory of two young boys, Tim Parry and Johnathan Ball, who were killed in an IRA bombing in Warrington, England.\\n\\n“This song is our cry against man’s inhumanity to man, inhumanity to child,” she said.\\n\\nDuring a performance of “Zombie” in January 1994 at The Astoria in London, Dolores O\'Riordan said:\\n\\nThis song is our cry against the violence in London, against the war in the north of Ireland. And we want it to stop.\",\"description\":{\"markdown\":\"The Cranberries describe the violence in \\\"The Troubles,\\\" the decades-long conflict in Northern Ireland between nationalists (mainly self-identified as Irish or Roman Catholic) and unionists (mainly self-identified as British or Protestant).\\n\\nDolores O\'Riordan wrote the song during the band\'s English tour in 1993 in memory of two young boys, Tim Parry and Johnathan Ball, who were killed in an IRA bombing in Warrington, England.\\n\\n>“This song is our cry against man’s inhumanity to man, inhumanity to child,” she said.\\n\\nDuring a performance of \\\"Zombie\\\" in January 1994 at The Astoria in London, Dolores O\'Riordan said:\\n\\n> This song is our cry against the violence in London, against the war in the north of Ireland. And we want it to stop.\",\"html\":\"<p>The Cranberries describe the violence in “The Troubles,” the decades-long conflict in Northern Ireland between nationalists (mainly self-identified as Irish or Roman Catholic) and unionists (mainly self-identified as British or Protestant).<\/p>\\n\\n<p>Dolores O\'Riordan wrote the song during the band’s English tour in 1993 in memory of two young boys, Tim Parry and Johnathan Ball, who were killed in an IRA bombing in Warrington, England.<\/p>\\n\\n<blockquote><p>“This song is our cry against man’s inhumanity to man, inhumanity to child,” she said.<\/p><\/blockquote>\\n\\n<p>During a performance of “Zombie” in January 1994 at The Astoria in London, Dolores O\'Riordan said:<\/p>\\n\\n<blockquote><p>This song is our cry against the violence in London, against the war in the north of Ireland. Troubles were not a conflict *between* Ireland and the UK (which are both sovereign countries). Instead, The Troubles were a period of sectarian violence *within* Northern Ireland (which is a part of the UK but not a part of Ireland). The Republicans, which were overwhelming catholic, wanted to see Northern Ireland join Ireland while the Unionists, who were overwhelming protestant, wanted to ensure Northern Ireland remained a part of the United Kingdom. Basically it was a civil war within the UK and not a war between Ireland the UK.\",\"html\":\"<p>The Troubles were not a conflict <em>between<\/em> Ireland and the UK (which are both sovereign countries). Instead, The Troubles were a period of sectarian violence <em>within<\/em> Northern Ireland (which is a part of the UK but not a part of Ireland). The Republicans, which were overwhelming catholic, wanted to see Northern Ireland join Ireland while the Unionists, who were overwhelming protestant, wanted to ensure Northern Ireland remained a part of the United Kingdom. Basically it was a civil war within the UK and not a war between Ireland the I remember being in my flat, coming up with the chorus, which was catchy and anthemic. So I took it into rehearsals, and I picked up the electric guitar. Then I kicked in distortion on the chorus, and I said to Ferg [Fergal Lawler, drums]: ‘Maybe you could beat the drums pretty hard.’ Even though it was written on an acoustic, it became a bit of a rocker....It came organically because we were using our live instruments, we were plugging in a lot, and we started to mess around with feedback and distortion. When you’re on tour you start to mess around a bit more with the live side of things. There were a lot of bands around that were part of the grunge thing, and this wasn’t grunge, but the timing was good. We couldn’t have really fitted in with grunge, because we were just a different type of a band. We were Irish and from Limerick, and we had a lot of our own ideas. A lot of the grunge bands were very similar to each other.\",\"body\":{\"markdown\":\"In an [interview with *Louder Sound,*](https://www.loudersound.com/features/the-story-behind-the-song-the-cranberries-zombie) O\'Riordian recalls:\\n\\n>It was extremely busy and we were working all the time around the clock,” she said. “That song came to me when I was in Limerick, and I wrote it initially on an acoustic guitar, late at night. I remember being in my flat, coming up with the chorus, which was catchy and anthemic. So I took it into rehearsals, and I picked up the electric guitar. Then I kicked in distortion on the chorus, and I said to Ferg [Fergal Lawler, drums]: ‘Maybe you could beat the drums pretty hard.’ Even though it was written on an acoustic, it became a bit of a rocker....It came organically because we were using our live instruments, we were plugging in a lot, and we started to mess around with feedback and distortion. When you’re on tour you start to mess around a bit more with the live side of things. There were a lot of bands around that were part of the grunge thing, and this wasn’t grunge, but the timing was good. We couldn’t have really fitted in with grunge, because we were just a different type of a band. We were Irish and from Limerick, and we had a lot of our own ideas. A lot of the grunge bands were very similar to each other.\",\"html\":\"<p>In an <a href=\\\"https://www.loudersound.com/features/the-story-behind-the-song-the-cranberries-zombie\\\" rel=\\\"noopener nofollow\\\">interview with <em>Louder Sound,<\/em><\/a> O\'Riordian recalls:<\/p>\\n\\n<blockquote><p>It was extremely busy and we were working all the time around the clock,” she said. “That song came to me when I was in Limerick, and I wrote it initially on an acoustic guitar, late at night. I remember being in my flat, coming up with the chorus, which was catchy and anthemic. So I took it into rehearsals, and I picked up the electric guitar. Then I kicked in distortion on the chorus, and I said to Ferg [Fergal Lawler, drums]: ‘Maybe you could beat the drums pretty hard.’ Even though it was written on an acoustic, it became a bit of a rocker….It came organically because we were using our live instruments, we were plugging in a lot, and we started to mess around with feedback and distortion. When you’re on tour you start to mess around a bit more with the live side of things. There were a lot of bands around that were part of the grunge thing, and this wasn’t grunge, but the timing was good. We couldn’t have really fitted in with grunge, because we were just a different type of a band. We were Irish and from Limerick, and we had a lot of our own ideas. A lot of the grunge bands were very similar to each
